hero.title: Plotter – Speech-to-Draw Machine
hero.oneLiner: A DIY plotter that turns spoken words into plotted drawings by converting speech to text, then text to vector strokes and G-code.

context.text: Most “voice” interfaces stop at transcription. I wanted voice to become a physical output, something you could hold and keep. The trigger was realizing that creative expression is often blocked by software skill and tooling. The constraint was to build a pipeline that felt magical but stayed understandable: speak, preview, plot, without expensive hardware or closed ecosystems.

bullets: DIY XY plotter hardware with pen lift mechanism
Speech-to-text pipeline to capture spoken input
G-code generation script for plotting within bounds
Plot preview + settings UI (bounds, scale, font selection)
Calibration routines for origin, scaling, and pen behavior

decisions.decision: Speech-to-text + plotting pipeline vs manual typing
decisions.why: Made creation faster and more accessible, with a “speak it into existence” feel.
decisions.tradeoff: Needed error handling for transcription mistakes.

decisions.decision: Bounds-based scaling near origin vs full-bed auto layout
decisions.why: Ensured predictable output and avoided edge crashes.
decisions.tradeoff: Required users to think in a constrained canvas.

decisions.why: Simpler mechanics and cheaper implementation for pen up/down.
decisions.tradeoff: More tuning for consistent lift height and timing.

worked: The end-to-end flow (voice → plot) created a strong “physical computing” moment.
Stroke-font rendering produced clean, plotter-friendly paths.
User-defined bounds prevented most mechanical overrun issues.
didnt: Pen-up timing and final-stroke completion were inconsistent and required repeated tuning.

outcome.text: The plotter reliably converted spoken input into plotted text and drawings, producing repeatable physical artifacts from voice. It became a platform for experimenting with typography, constraints, and computational art, not just a one-off build.

reflection.text: This project clarified how a simple pipeline design can turn a familiar input (voice) into a surprising medium (paper), as long as constraints are explicit and controllable.
